poem:
Title: Dawn at the Boxing Ring

In a scene set on the far side of the moon,
a woman laces her gloves with laughter,
a ring of light playing in a Chinese cinema.
Under the sign of Yolo, she spar-sprays sweat and jubilation,
her fists, the poets of resilience.
Not wolf nor epic, but a life in swift blossoms,
one right hook at the mundane's jaw.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Knockout success of Yolo – the feelgood female boxing movie from China In a country where cinemas are normally dominated by wolf warrior blockbusters or nationalist historical epics, the surprise hit of China’s box office in 2024 is a feelgood comedy about a woman who transforms her lacklustre life – and herself – through boxing. Released for the lunar new year holiday on 10 February, Yolo (You Only Live Once) has become the highest grossing". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
